results.title: Words and silk
results.creator_credit: Kangaroo Films, Philip Tyndall and John Cruthers
results.brief_description: A two part program about the life and works of Australian fiction writer, Gerald Murnane. Pt. 1. The imaginary and real world of Gerald Murnane (41 min.) The first part explores his imaginary world and presents images both of Murnane’s childhood in Victoria during the 1940’s and of his interests, particularly his obsession with horseracing. Pt. 2. The real and imaginary world of Gerald Murnane (45 min.) In the second part Murnane discusses his writing style and reads extracts from Tamarisk Row to show how he weaves his interests and obsessions into his work.

results.title: Words and music
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Arthur Freed and Norman Taurog
results.brief_description: A musical version of the lives and work of Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart featuring twenty-two of their songs. Cast includes Mickey Rooney (Lorenz Hart), Tom Drake (Richard Rodgers), Marshall Thompson, Janet Leigh, Betty Garrett, Ann Sothern, June Allyson, Perry Como, Judy Garland, Lena Horne, Gene Kelly.

results.title: Words and labels
results.creator_credit: Centre for Educational Television and Lawrie Lawler
results.brief_description: Explains the methods and techniques for showing printing and writing on a television screen, including the presenter’s over handwriting. Stresses the need for good timing and rehearsals. Some suggestions are made on dealing with awkward or unusually shaped objects. Companion film to “Graphics and Superimposition”.

results.title: Word processing: worries and wonders
results.brief_description: Users of word processors volunteer answers about their jobs including the doubts some had before starting, the equipment, their work relationships and the satisfactions of their careers in word processing.

results.title: Word processing: kissing the girls goodbye
results.brief_description: Once upon a time there was a guy called “the boss” - it was a lonely job. He has to get his own coffee, make pone calls, write his own letters and still run his business. So he hire “his girl” or secretary to assist him whilst he ran the business. She was a kind of servant, messenger and scribe. Today there are tens of millions scattered throughout organisations. Studies have found secretaries skills are not being fully utilised but paper processing is exploding. To the rescue comes world processing and re-organising of secretarial duties.

results.title: Woomera 2002
results.brief_description: Woomera is a notorious mandatory detention centre in South Australia, a particularly arid and inhospitable part of the desert. In 2002, about one thousand people gathered at Woomera to protest about the Government’s policy of mandatory detention for asylum seekers. When the protestors erect a temporary camp two hundred metres from the centre, the federal police arrive to dismantle their efforts; when they meet resistance, a scuffle ensues. Despite this, the protestors make it over to the interior camp fence and talk to the detainees, who are clearly perturbed and distressed by their ongoing imprisonment. A chaotic scene ensues with detainees attempting to escape, aided by the protestors, as the police try to stop the action. This locally made work is a telling document about a particularly contentious chapter in Australian history that continues to divide opinions about this policy.

results.title: Woolloomooloo
results.brief_description: A social and historical documentary on the redevelopment of one of Sydney’s oldest harbourside areas, from the initial plans of 1969 to the completion of the Housing Commission’s renovation project in late 1977. Details the roles of local, State and Federal governments, the State Planning Authority, The National Trust, the developers, the Builders’ Labourers Federation led by Jack Mundey, and the residents groups.

results.title: Woollen piece
results.creator_credit: New Zealand National Film Unit and Arthur Everard
results.brief_description: This film shows the rounding up of sheep, droving, shearing, hand carding, spinning and weaving by a variety of people, dyeing, design and the finished products. With virtually no commentary, the film relies on excerpts from lectures on spinning and weaving, design, tapestry etc. to make its points. Scenes of New Zealand are interspersed throughout.

results.title: Woolen goods
results.brief_description: Traces the sources of wool; contrasts methods of shering, cvarding, spinning and waving homespun and factory-made woollens; and follows through the operation involved in making an overcoat from the preliminary testing of the fabrics to the final pressing of the coat and its sale.
